title: 104_s844
content: The "Medicaid Flexibility Act of 1995" allows for block grants to states for health care services to needy individuals under Title XIX of the Social Security Act. The purpose of Sec. 1901 is to strengthen families by promoting economic independence through consolidating Federal assistance into a single grant for health care services and needy individuals. States are given flexibility to enforce requirements such as school attendance, immunizations, drug restrictions, and time limits on assistance. The purpose of Sec. 1901 is to promote economic independence by consolidating Federal assistance into a single grant for health care services and needy individuals. States have flexibility to enforce requirements such as school attendance, immunizations, drug restrictions, and time limits on assistance. This purpose includes measures like requiring mothers to identify the father of their child, denying assistance to illegal aliens, and involving private sector organizations in providing health care services funded by the States. "Payments to states for health care services and needy individuals are consolidated into a single grant, allowing states flexibility in enforcing requirements such as school attendance, immunizations, and drug restrictions." Each State is entitled to quarterly payments for fiscal years 1996-2000 equal to 25% of the annual amount determined under paragraph (2) for carrying out the purpose described in section 1901. The annual amount is determined as 105% of the previous fiscal year's amount received under this title. The Secretary of the Treasury will make quarterly payments to each State directly in accordance with section 6503 of title 31, United States Code. States must expend funds received under this title within the fiscal year or the following year, except for amounts set aside for unexpected assistance needs. Any remaining funds after 2000 must be used for the purpose described in section 1901 of this title. A State may use up to 30 percent of the annual amount paid under this title for certain State programs specified in the law. Funds used for these programs are not subject to the requirements of this title but must comply with the rules for Federal funds provided directly under the specific law. "administrative and fiscal accountability" Sec. 1903 requires states to conduct annual audits of their expenditures from funds received under this title to ensure compliance with the regulations. The audits must be performed by an approved entity following accepted auditing principles. States must conduct annual audits of their expenditures from funds received under this title to ensure compliance. The audits must be performed by an approved entity independent of any agency administering activities funded under this title. States must submit audit reports to the State legislature and the Secretary of the Treasury within 30 days. Any amounts found to have been improperly expended must be repaid to the United States plus a 10% penalty. The Secretary of the Treasury may offset penalties against amounts owed to the State. Additional accounting requirements apply to audit provisions. States must submit annual reports on fund activities following accounting principles. The State must submit annual reports on fund activities following accepted accounting principles, including audit results, and provide copies for public inspection. The Secretary of the Treasury supervises the funds received under this title by making quarterly payments to states, approving entities, and ensuring compliance with section 1902(b). Limited Federal Oversight: No federal department or agency, except the Department of the Treasury and the Attorney General as specified in section 1904, can supervise the funds allocated to states under this title. No other federal entity can regulate the purpose of this title. The curr_chunk is about "nondiscrimination provisions" in federal oversight. The curr_chunk discusses nondiscrimination provisions in federally funded programs based on disability, sex, race, color, or national origin. Compliance with these provisions is required to receive funding. The Secretary of the Treasury shall notify the state's chief executive officer to secure compliance with nondiscrimination provisions in federally funded programs. If compliance is not secured within 60 days, the Secretary may refer the matter to the Attorney General, utilize powers under various civil rights acts, or take other legal actions. The Attorney General may bring civil actions in district court for relief, including injunctive relief, when a matter is referred or if there is reason to believe an entity is violating the law. Nondiscrimination and institutional safeguards for religious providers. Sec. 1905 allows religious and charitable organizations to provide health care services under this title without compromising their religious character or freedom. Religious organizations cannot be discriminated against based on their religious mission when applying to be health care providers funded under this title. Religious organizations providing health care services funded under this title can maintain independence and control over their religious beliefs. They have the right to hire, promote, discipline, and dismiss based on religion. However, they cannot deny services based on religion. The government cannot require religious providers to compromise their beliefs. Religious organizations providing health care services funded under this title may need to alter their internal governance or facilities, including removing religious symbols, to be eligible as providers. They must also adhere to fiscal accountability regulations similar to other providers. Religious organizations receiving federal funds under this title must follow auditing principles and may segregate funds for separate accounts. Violations of their rights can be enforced through civil action. Beneficiaries of assistance have rights under this section. Each State must provide a certificate to beneficiaries who object to receiving health care services from a religious organization funded under this title. The certificate can be redeemed with another provider for services of equal value. Providers cannot give cash in exchange for these certificates. "Emergency assistance is available for beneficiaries who object to receiving health care services from a religious organization funded under this title." Sec. 1906 states that health care services funded under this title must be provided to eligible individuals, including emergency medical treatment, as long as they meet the eligibility requirements and the services are not related to an organ transplant procedure. The text chunk discusses symptoms that require immediate medical attention to prevent serious health risks or organ dysfunction. The Balanced Budget and Emergency Deficit Control Act of 1985 is amended to change grants to states for Medicaid to block grants for health care services to needy individuals. The amendments will be effective on October 1, 1995.
